transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Hi everyone, I’m really glad to see you all today. Before we begin, let’s do a quick check-in. In one word, how are you feeling right now?

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: Tired.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: Stressed.

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: Good.

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: A bit overwhelmed.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: Calm.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Thank you for sharing. I appreciate the honesty. It sounds like some of you have had long days. Today we’re talking about something that can really help during stressful times—growth mindset.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Growth mindset is the belief that abilities can be developed through dedication and hard work. It means effort matters more than talent. Instead of thinking ‘I’m just not smart,’ we think ‘I can improve with practice.’ What do you think that means in real life?

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: Like studying more if you fail?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, that’s a great example. Studying differently or putting in more effort can help you improve.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: But some people are naturally smarter.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That’s a common thought. People may start at different levels, but research shows the brain is like a muscle. The more you use it, the stronger it becomes. What happens to a muscle if you train it consistently?

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: It gets stronger.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly. The same idea applies to learning.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: I failed my last math test even though I tried.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like that was really disappointing. In a growth mindset, failure isn’t proof that you can’t do it—it’s information. It shows you that you may need a new strategy. What could be a different approach next time?

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: Maybe practicing more questions.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That’s a strong plan.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Let’s compare two thoughts. Fixed mindset says: ‘I’m bad at science.’ Growth mindset says: ‘I’m not good at science yet, but I can improve.’ What differences do you notice?

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: One sounds final, the other sounds hopeful.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: I like how you put that—hopeful. That word is powerful.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Let’s do a short activity. Think of something you used to struggle with but got better at. Who would like to share?

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: I used to be bad at public speaking, but I improved after practicing.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That’s a great example of growth mindset in action. You practiced, and your ability developed.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: I improved in football after training more.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, consistent effort builds skill over time.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Sometimes when we fail, we feel embarrassed. That’s normal. Growth mindset doesn’t mean we ignore feelings. It means we learn from failure instead of letting it define us. Has anyone experienced that shift before?

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: I guess when I kept trying in chemistry and finally passed.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That persistence really paid off. Thank you for sharing that.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: I’d also love to hear from someone who hasn’t spoken much yet. Maybe Member4—what’s one area you’d like to grow in?

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: Probably writing essays.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Thanks for jumping in. What small step could help you improve there?

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: Practicing introductions more.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That’s specific and actionable. Great thinking.

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: What if you try and still don’t improve quickly?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That can feel frustrating. Growth mindset also includes adjusting strategies—asking for help, trying new methods, or practicing consistently. Improvement isn’t always fast, but small steps add up.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Let’s reflect quietly for 30 seconds. What is one challenge you’re currently facing where a growth mindset could help?

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: Math exams.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: Learning guitar.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: Managing study time.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: Confidence in class.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Thank you. Now, what is one small action you can take this week toward that challenge?

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: Practice 15 minutes daily.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: Speak once in each class.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: Do extra practice problems.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Those are strong growth mindset steps. Remember, effort matters more than talent, and the brain grows with practice.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: I feel less stuck thinking about it this way.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: I’m really glad to hear that. Shifting how we think can open new possibilities.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Before we close, can someone summarize what growth mindset means in their own words?

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: It means you can improve your abilities if you keep trying and learn from failure.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Excellent summary. That captures it perfectly.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: This week, notice when you have a fixed mindset thought like ‘I can’t do this.’ Pause and add the word ‘yet.’ Then take one small action. We’ll discuss how it went next time.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Thank you all for your participation today. I appreciate how respectfully you listened to each other. See you next session.
